24.title: Freshman Seminar
24.description: The Freshman Seminar Program has been designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small-seminar setting. Freshman seminars are offered in all campus departments, and topics vary from department to department and semester to semester. Enrollment limited to 15 freshmen.

141.title: Chicana Feminist Writers and Discourse
141.description: A critical and theoretical analysis of contemporary Chicana Writers and Chicana Feminist Discourse.

150B.title: History of the Southwest: Mexican-United States War to Present
150B.description: The relationship between people of Mexican descent and American society from 1880 to the present.

50.title: Introduction to Chicano History
50.description: A general overview of the Chicano historical experience in the U.S.

180AC.title: Topics in Chicano Studies
180AC.description: This course will introduce students to specific Chicana/Latina, Native, Asian, & African American art history and cultural practices developed as an essential aesthetic of art made by Artists of Color in the Bay Area. Focus is placed on the politics, ideas, and methods for working in community that are still viable and integral to current art practice with a commitment to social justice. The course will offer hands-on experience in community schools and organizations. Art experience welcome but not required.

97.title: Field Study in Chicano Studies
97.description: Supervised independent field experience in the community relevant to specific aspects of Chicano studies.

R1B.title: Reading and Composition
R1B.description: This course examines literary works by Chicano/a writers in their political and social contexts. Emphasis is on literary interpretation and sustained analytical writing. The course aims to develop students' fluency in writing longer and more complex papers, with specific attention to the development of their research skills and their ability to incorporate source material effectively. Satisfies the second half of the Reading and Composition Requirement.

165.title: Cuba, the United States and Cuban Americans
165.description: This course examines the contested formation of Cuban identity, where the questions of race and the relationship to the United States have constituted fundamental issues in the debate over the meaning of Cubanidad. The course will address the ways in which Cuba dealt with the issue of race and national identity after the revolution of 1959, as well as, for the Cuban emigre community in the United States. Issues of gender, class, and cultural expression will be crucial elements of analysis throughout the course.

159.title: Mexican Immigration
159.description: This course provides an overview of Mexican immigration to the United States. The relationship between immigration and Chicano community formation will be examined. Issues addressed include settlement patterns, socialization, educational aspiration, identity transformation, and historical changes.

135B.title: Latino Narrative Film Since 1990
135B.description: This course examines major narrative films produced since the 1980s that deal with the Latino/Chicano experience and the influences that shaped the views reflected in those cinematic works. Films produced in the U.S. and in Latin America will be encompassed by the course.

110.title: Latina/o Philosophy and Religious Thought
110.description: For the last 30 years, the themes of identity and liberation have dominated the social ethic and religious thought of subaltern subjectivities in the Americas. The centrality of these ideas respond to the increasing awareness of and opposition to the legacies of the history of conquest, colonization, racism, and sexism in the region. In this course, we are going to study the intellectual production of various ethnic groups in the Americas, particularly Latinas and Latinos in the 20th century, in order to clarify the ties between concerns for cultural and religious identity and the articulation of alternative ethical and political visions.

198.title: Directed Group Study
198.description: Directed group study in Chicano Studies for advanced students. Regular meetings with faculty sponsor and written reports required.

98.title: Supervised Group Study
98.description: Group study of selected topics which will vary from semester to semester.

197.title: Field Work in Chicano Studies
197.description: Supervised independent field experience in the community relevant to specific aspects of Chicano Studies. Regular meetings with faculty sponsor and written reports required.

199.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research
199.description: Independent work for advanced students in Chicano Studies. Regular individual meetings with faculty sponsor and written reports required.

180.title: Topics in Chicano Studies
180.description: Topics in Latino/a-related art, history and contemporary issues, such as neighborhood development (e.g., Fruitvale neighborhood of Oakland, Mission district of San Francisco), mural arts movements, Spanish-language media, labor history, unionization efforts, immigration, demographic shifts, regional economic and/or social history, and transnational communities.  Course topics will vary with the expertise of the particular instructor.

20.title: Introduction to Chicano Culture
20.description: An introduction to the cultural life of Chicanos with its regional differences. Key themes are the symbols and cultural norms created by the historical interaction between Chicanos and American society as expressed in literature, art, music, and folklore. Attention will also be given to change and continuity in Chicano cultural norms on the basis of historical events.

172.title: Chicanos and the Educational System
172.description: An examination of the historical and contemporary relationship between the educational system and the Mexican community in the United States; the history of schooling practices within the Mexican population as a backdrop to an examination of the current educational conditions of the Chicano students; the different historical trends in the education of Chicanos including alternative schools, bilingual education, school segregation, and higher education.

161.title: Central American Peoples and Cultures
161.description: A comparative survey of the peoples and cultures of the countries of the Central American Isthmus from a historical and contemporary perspective.

176.title: Chicanos and Health Care
176.description: Relationship of the health care delivery system in the U.S. to the Chicano community. To include an examination and understanding of the concept of mental health as defined by Chicanos. Analysis of program alternatives and the Chicano response to health care problems and issues.

195.title: Senior Thesis
195.description: Writing of a thesis under the direction of the member(s) of the faculty.

H195B.title: Senior Honors Thesis for Chicano Studies Majors
H195B.description: Course for senior Chicano Studies majors designed to support and guide the writing of a senior honors thesis. For senior Chicano Studies majors who have been approved for the honors program.

152.title: The History of Latina/o Studies
152.description: Latinas/os have long been the object of intellectual thought: they have been written about, they have been studied and quantified, and quite often not in positive terms. In this course, we will turn Latinas/os from objects of discourse to subjects of discourse, as active participants in intellectual thought. Our goal will be to explore how Latinas/os have reflected critically upon and written about their position as Latinas/os within the United States. In doing so, we will counter the general notion that Latina/o intellectual thought is, at best, a recent phenomenon or, at worst, non-existent.

174.title: Chicanos, Law, and Criminal Justice
174.description: An examination of the development and function of law, the organization and administration of criminal justice, and their effects in the Chicano community; response to these institutions by Chicanos.

99.title: Supervised Independent Study and Research
99.description: Individual research by lower division students. Limited to freshmen and sophomores.

R1A.title: Reading and Composition
R1A.description: Course will acquaint students with methods of expository discourse through the reading of Chicano/a literature. An introduction to writing, beginning with sentence structure, with an emphasis on unity, coherence, and overall organization of a full composition. Satisfies the first half of the Reading and Composition Requirement.
